item.title: World leaders applaud peace agreement between Israel and Hamas
item.description: Several world leaders welcomed the peace agreement between Israel and Hamas announced by US President Donald Trump, praising the imminent end of the war in Gaza and the release of hostages after two years of conflict. Trump announced on Wednesday that Israel and the Islamist movement have accepted the “first phase” of his peace plan, which envisages the partial withdrawal of Israeli troops from the Gaza Strip and the release of 20 hostages still alive in exchange for Palestinian prisoners. “All hostages will be released very soon and Israel will withdraw its troops to an agreed line as first steps towards a strong, lasting and eternal peace,” Trump wrote on the Truth Social network. The news was received with enthusiasm by leaders from several countries. Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney congratulated Trump on his “essential leadership” and expressed relief at the imminent release of the hostages. "Peace finally seems possible. We urge all parties to quickly implement the terms of the agreement," he said. Japan also welcomed the understanding, which government spokesman Yoshimasa Hayashi classified as “an important step to calm the situation”, thanking the United States, Egypt and Qatar for their mediation efforts. From Canberra, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and Foreign Minister Penny Wong highlighted that it was “a very necessary step towards peace” and defended a two-state solution, stressing that the plan excludes Hamas from any role in the future administration of Gaza. United Nations Secretary-General António Guterres described the agreement as “a desperately needed breakthrough” and called for its full implementation, stressing that “it is an opportunity to recognize the right to self-determination of the Palestinian people and move towards a two-state solution”. Hamas confirmed the understanding, guaranteeing that it “ensures the end of the war, the withdrawal of the Israeli army and the entry of humanitarian aid”, and called on Israel to fulfill its commitments “without delays or changes”. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called the deal a “historic achievement” and thanked Trump for his “determined leadership and global efforts,” saying: “With God’s help, we will bring everyone home.” Euphoria and relief According to official sources, the release of the hostages is expected to begin on Monday, after the agreement is approved by the Israeli Government, and the military withdrawal will cover around 70 percent of the Gaza territory. “This is more than Gaza, it is the beginning of peace in the Middle East,” said Trump in an interview with Fox News, assuring that the United States and neighboring countries will support the reconstruction of the enclave. He added: "Other countries in the region will help because they have immense wealth. We will be involved to ensure Gaza is successful and peaceful." In Tel Aviv, families of the hostages gathered in euphoria in Hostage Square, amid tears and chants of “Nobel for Trump”. “I want to smell my son,” said Einav Zangauker, mother of one of the hostages, emotionally. In Gaza, where the ceasefire was met with a mixture of relief and distrust, displaced people and residents expressed hope of being able to return to their homes. “We want to return, even if there are no more houses,” said Alaa Abd Rabbo, displaced from the north of the Strip. The agreement brokered by the United States, Qatar, Egypt and Türkiye marks the most significant attempt to end the war since the conflict began in October 2023.

item.title: Overseas Chinese | Lam calls for continuity in promoting Macau
item.description: The Secretary for Social Affairs and Culture, O Lam, defended the continuation, by the General Association of Overseas Chinese of Macau, of the work to promote the territory, at a time when the entity celebrated, on Wednesday, 57 years of existence. According to a statement, O Lam said, in a speech, that the association should promote the specific advantages of Macau as a Sino-Lusophone platform in addition to assuming the bridge between China, Portugal and Portuguese-speaking countries, as well as Spanish-speaking countries. Lam also hopes that the association will continue to support local and Mainland Chinese companies in accessing international markets, in addition to supporting the import of certain international projects to China. This is so that Macau can explore the “circle of friends” and partners at an international level, supporting the country’s development in opening up to the outside world.

item.title: UnionPay | First branch opened in Macau
item.description: Macau already has a branch of UnionPay International, a subsidiary of China UnionPay, reported the Macau News Agency portal. This is the first bank card organization to make this commitment, and the objective of opening the branch is to expand international business. Macau became the “second region abroad” to accept transactions with UnionPay cards since the company launched this service in 2004 in the territory. Regarding digital payments, UnionPay's investment took place in 2018 in the territories of Macau and Hong Kong, with the “QuickPass” application and an EMV-compatible QR code being launched in Macau, that is, “Europay, Mastercard and Visa”, which are the three companies behind the global standard for secure card payments. In 2019, Apple Pay was launched in Macau with technological support from UnionPay.

item.title: Cinema | Casa de Macau in Lisbon displays “Heritople”
item.description: The “CineMacau – Macau Documentary Cinema Cycle” session will take place next Wednesday, October 15th, starting at 4:30 pm, at Casa de Macau in Lisbon. The film “Heritople”, by António Salas Sanmarful, made last year, will be shown, followed by a conversation with the director himself who may be present via video conference. The cinema sessions at Casa de Macau are organized and curated by Ruka Borges, a director linked to Macau, and Gonçalo Magalhães, member of the Casa's board of directors, who ensure the thematic framework of the films. The documentary in question was recently produced by António Monteiro (IIM) and directed by António Salas Sanmarful with support from the Macau International Institute, having gained notoriety in promoting Macau as a city and/or territory with a unique hybrid culture, steeped in its heritage and legacy of the East-West relationship, which also highlights the contribution of the Macanese in this odyssey, and describes the organization of the event. Thus, “Heritople” ends up reinforcing “the importance of Macau as a tangible and intangible heritage of the world given its unique and singular particularities on the occasion of the 25th anniversary of the construction of the MSAR as a reality in the context of the People's Republic of China”.

item.title: Central Library | 30 proposals received for the creation of a superstructure
item.description:
Once the construction of the foundations and basements of the project designed by the Mecanoo studio has been completed, the construction of the superstructure of the New Macau Central Library should take place by the end of the year
The public competition for the award of works on the superstructure of the New Macau Central Library resulted in the presentation of 30 proposals. The opening of the documents presented yesterday by the candidates was held yesterday, at the headquarters of the Directorate of Public Works Services (DSOP). The public tender was launched on August 21st and defines 620 days as the maximum period for construction of this phase of the project located in Tap Seac. Work on the superstructure should also begin by the end of the year, after the construction of the foundations and basements is completed. According to the Government, the new project will make it possible to “solve” the “problem of lack of space in the current central library”, in addition to fulfilling the “mission of promoting reading for the entire population, cultural exchange and showcasing local characteristics”. Proposals will be evaluated based on price (a criterion weighing 50 percent in the decision), execution time (15 percent), experience and quality of works (20 percent), execution program (10 percent) and also taking into account the human resources program plan and proportion of resident workers in management positions (5 percent). The future library will occupy an area of ​​around 2,960 square meters and the project envisages the construction of four floors in height and a basement, with a gross construction area of ​​around 13,800 square meters. According to official data, this construction area is “ten times larger than that of the old central library”, located on the opposite side of Praça do Tap Seac. The ground floor and upper floors of the building will contain facilities such as auditoriums, a newspaper and magazine reading area, libraries for adults and children, meeting rooms and multimedia spaces dedicated to teaching. Troubled project The construction of the new library in Macau has been planned for more than 10 years, with the processes of choosing the location and preparing the project being marked by several controversies. Initially, during Fernando Chui Sai On's second term as Chief Executive, an invitation to Portuguese architect Álvaro Siza Vieira was revealed to design the future library. However, due to pressure from local interest groups, the invitation to the Portuguese architect was withdrawn, which led to a public competition. As part of the first competition, a project from the architect Carlos Marreiros' studio was chosen, with a price of 18.68 million patacas. The library was planned for the old courthouse. However, the works never started, because faced with criticism about the planned location, the Executive decided to choose a new location, the current one, located in Praça do Tap Seac and which involved the demolition of the old Hotel Estoril. The changes led to another public competition, this time international, which ended with the choice of the Dutch studio Mecanoo. It is this project that is now being built.

item.title: Study | Game is a factor of stability
item.description:
The work published at the beginning of the month highlights the importance of gambling for the local economy and warns against adventures in economic diversification that could jeopardize local stability
An industry susceptible to being affected by regional and global political and economic uncertainties, but also highly resilient and should be seen as a factor of stability in the territory. These are some conclusions of the study entitled “Regional and Global Uncertainty and the Impacts on the Tourism and Gaming Industry of Macau”, published in the magazine Cogent Economics & Finance by academic Tang Chi Chong. In the research, published on October 3, it is recognized that regional and global uncertainties “may influence gambling revenues” in Macau, and changes in the economic and political environments will have an impact on gambling revenues. This impact is expected in terms of betting in casinos, especially if the uncertainties occur in places such as the Interior, Hong Kong, Taiwan or South Korea, the Macao SAR's main tourist markets. “Macau’s gaming industry is not isolated from the outside world”, it is acknowledged. However, the study also concludes that Macau's tourism is highly resilient to negative impacts compared to traditional tourism markets, where gambling is less important. “Macau’s hotel sector is less sensitive to global risks and uncertainties compared to traditional hotel sectors, largely due to the presence of the gaming industry”, it is justified. "However, the impacts of regional and global uncertainty are not significant for Macau's pillar industry. The city's gaming sector demonstrates strong resilience in the face of economic and political instability, both regionally and globally", it was added. Protect the chicken In view of these conclusions, the study argues that the gaming industry must be protected, even in an environment in which attempts are made to diversify Macau's economy. "It is clear that the integration of the gaming industry into Macau's tourism sector increases the overall resilience of the city's tourism and hospitality industry. Economic diversification has been a key policy of the Macau government. However, special attention should be paid to the sensitivity of different industries compared to the gaming sector", he was warned. "If the gaming industry demonstrates high resilience to uncertainty, maintaining it could be a viable strategy to stabilize the economy. Furthermore, resilience to uncertainty could serve as a key criterion for the government in selecting industries for development, as it contributes to economic stability in a context of increasing global economic and political uncertainty," it was added. Tang Chi Chong is linked to the Macau Polytechnic University, Macau Tourism University and the Hong Kong Polytechnic University.

item.title: Commerce | Golden Week below expectations
item.description:
Although the number of tourists increased by 15.3 percent compared to last year, when it came to opening their wallets, people were more careful. The climate of disappointment was described by the president of the Federation of Industry and Commerce of Macau Center and South Districts
A Golden Week far from satisfactory. This was how Lei Cheok Kuan, president of the Federation of Industry and Commerce of Macau Central and South Districts, defined the most recent holidays. The balance of the days that lasted between October 1st and Wednesday was made by the person responsible in statements to the newspaper Exmoo. According to Lei Cheok Kuan, the impact on local businesses was “disappointing”, because although the territory received around 1.14 million tourists, the number did not translate into an increase in revenue for local businesses. The association leader acknowledged that reality fell short of expectations, because the gains on the Chinese stock markets since the beginning of the year suggested greater spending power for visitors. “It wasn’t just in my goldsmith shop [that business was worse], the traders I know in restaurants and retail sales, including those in the Rua dos Ervanários area, also saw business performing worse than in the past”, lamented the president of the association. Lei Cheok Kuan pointed out that the flow of tourists to the Ruins of São Paulo was high, but that more tourists did not generate more consumption. The person responsible admitted that expenses were below what had happened in May, during national holidays around Labor Day. As reasons for weaker consumption, the president of the association put forward as hypotheses the impact of the slowdown in the economy in the interior, which makes consumers less spendy. Furthermore, the president pointed out that the consumption model of generation Z has changed, becoming more demanding, which may mean that they cannot find what they are looking for in Macau. Pedestrian zone disappointed Regarding the new temporary pedestrian zone on Rua de Nossa Senhora do Amparo, Lei Cheok Kuan confessed that he had many hopes. The expectation was for a large concentration of tourists in the place and greater consumption. However, the reality was different than expected. Lei Cheok Kuan pointed out that few traders felt the results of the initiative. Therefore, the person in charge concluded that despite the Government trying to find new methods to support small and medium-sized companies, consumers are increasingly changing their consumption habits, which makes the task more difficult. However, Lei Cheok Kuan defended the need for traders to adapt and better understand the way young people like to spend money. During the eight days of Golden Week, the territory received 1.14 million tourists, which represented an increase of 15.3 percent compared to last year. On average, 143.1 thousand people visited the Macao SAR per day, an increase of approximately 1 percent compared to last year. Accounts done Macau received more than 1.1 million visitors in the first week of October, during the holidays commemorating China's National Day, the Tourism Services Bureau (DST) announced yesterday. The total number of visitors during Golden Week, from October 1 to 8, was 1,144,351, 16.5 percent more than last year's 982,542, which had one less day (October 1 to 7), according to data published on the DST website. This year, it was on October 4th that Macau recorded the highest number of visitors, with 191,132 tourists entering the territory. The lowest number of visitors during the “Golden Week” was seen on the eighth day, October 8, with 88,943 entries, according to that direction. This year, the 76th anniversary of the founding of the People's Republic of China was celebrated.

item.title: Education | UM considered the 145th best in the world
item.description:
In just over 10 years, Macau's largest public educational institution managed to rise to the top of the best universities worldwide. In a ranking led by the most famous institutions, MUST and Cidade Universidade de Macau also appear
The University of Macau (UM) was yesterday considered the 145th best in the world, according to the Times Higher Education 2026 magazine ranking. In the space of 11 years, the public educational institution rose from 500th place to 145th position in the ranking. On a scale of 0 to 100 points, UM was evaluated by Times Higher Education with a total of 62 points, compared to 59.7 points in the previous year. The area in which the institution achieved the best score was in the “research quality” index with 92.9 points, followed by “international perspectives”, in which it obtained 92.5 points. According to ranking information, more than 51 percent of the institution's students are classified as international students. Despite this, international perspectives were the only area in which the university performed worse than the previous year. Another aspect in which the institution stood out was in the industry index, which measures financing by companies to the institution, with 87 points. The areas in which the University of Macau presented a lower quality performance were in teaching (40.2 points) and also in the research environment (40.9 points). MUST and City In terms of Macau universities present in the 2026 ranking, the second best ranked is the Macau University of Science and Technology (MUST, in English), which appears between places 251 and 300 in the ranking. From 201st position onwards, the ranking stops specifying the specific position of the institutions and places them in groups of 50 universities, 100 universities or 200 universities. MUST obtained an overall score between 54.3 and 56.3 points, maintaining the same position since the 2024 ranking. Still, it is below the level reached in 2023 when it managed to enter the group of institutions in positions 201 to 250. The private institution obtained 93.2 points in international perspectives, 84.4 points at industry level, 81.1 points in research quality, 38.8 points in research environment and 34.2 points at teaching level. Cidade Universidade de Macau made its debut in the ranking this year, joining the group of institutions occupying between 601st and 800th places. The institution recorded a score between 39 and 43.5 points. The aspect in which it stood out best was international perspectives with 93.5 points, followed by research quality with 59.7 points. Teaching achieved 30.8 points, while industry achieved 18.9 points and 17.1 points in the research environment. This year the ranking was once again led by the University of Oxford, with an overall score of 98.2 points. The best university in the Interior is Tsinghua University in 12th place in the ranking, with 93 points. The University of Hong Kong appears in 33rd position, with 80.5 points. The best Portuguese institutions are the University of Coimbra, University of Lisbon and University of Porto, all included in the group classified between positions 401 and 500.

item.title: GP Macau: First names and first questions
item.description:
October is usually the month of preparations for the Macau Grand Prix. With the championships coming to an end all over the world, attention turns to the Macao SAR's big event, which this year will take place from the 13th to the 16th of November
After Marcos Cheong and Vernice Lau raced in the Chinese Formula 4 Championship race, this weekend it is Tiago Rodrigues' turn to pick up the helmet again to compete in the closing race of the Chinese competition season, on the circuit in the neighboring city of Zhuhai. The former Chinese champion of the discipline has been away from single-seater racing since participating in the Middle East Formula 4 Championship at the beginning of the year, but his experience could prove to be an asset in defending the territory's colors at the Guia Circuit. Twenty of the Mygale M21-F4 single-seaters from the Chinese championship will be overhauled after this race at the Zhuhai International Circuit and handed over to technicians appointed by the French Motor Sport Federation (FFSA), who will put them on the track in the first edition of the FIA ​​Formula 4 World Cup, in Macau. This is the same model used in the French Formula 4 Championship. Some names of the bikes Michael Rutter's absence from the entry list for this year's Macau Motorcycle Grand Prix is ​​now a certainty. However, through the specialized press, the first names that will shape the only road race on the Asian continent are beginning to become known. Practically confirmed are the presence of Davey Todd, winner of last year's edition, and Peter Hickman, the motorcyclist who chases Rutter's record of victories and who should be practically recovered from the injuries suffered in the accident on the Isle of Man. Both will drive the official competitive BMW M1000RR from 8TEN Racing. Rob Hodson, SMT Racing driver, has also guaranteed his presence in the Macao SAR, usually being one of the strong candidates for the Top 5 in the race. But not only renowned names are tested. Among the debutants already confirmed is ramp driver Maurizio Bottalico. The San Marino driver, who reached the podium at the Manx Grand Prix, follows in the footsteps of other great Italian names in 21st century road racing — such as Stefano Bonetti, Luca Gottardi or Alex Polita — by taking on the most famous and feared race in the East. According to the Road Racing News portal, there will be more newcomers to the Guia Circuit this year, such as Mitch Rees, a driver with several titles in New Zealand, Ryan Whitehall, a driver from the Isle of Wight, and the new holder of the Frohburger Dreieck lap record in the Supersport category, Paul Jordan. Questions in the GT Stéphane Ratel, founder and CEO of SRO Motorsports Group — the company that co-organizes the FIA ​​GT World Cup Macau Grand Prix — has been one of the most critical voices regarding the introduction of torque sensors in GT3 racing. However, the FIA ​​decided in favor of its use in the Guia Circuit World Cup, and the French businessman spoke about the matter for the first time. "The teams competing in Macau are mostly from Asia, where torque sensors have never been used. The lack of experience could affect the sporting balance, and that's why I opposed their use", said Stéphane Ratel to the German magazine Motorsport Aktuell, adding that he does not believe this is the way forward. Although the SRO Motorsports Group is co-organizer of the event and has a Balance of Performance (BoP) recognized worldwide, in the last two years the Macau BoP has been determined by the FIA ​​itself. Last year, the FIA's BoP was subject to a series of criticisms, with teams and drivers – particularly from Audi, Porsche and Lamborghini, the main losers – publicly expressing their displeasure at the differences in pace. For this reason, the FIA ​​decided to introduce these expensive sensors, installed on the cars' transmission shafts, which represent the most accurate tool for measuring the power transmitted to the wheels. “Some manufacturers supported the idea, but others, like Mercedes, were against it,” said Stéphane Ratel. "As a result, we lost some cars from the entry list. To be clear: I look at this issue pragmatically, not dogmatically. Last year in Macau, three or four manufacturers could have won without these torque sensors. In 2025 we will see if this technology is really useful", he concluded.

item.title: “Hush!” | Four dozen bands in two days of full celebration
item.description: The poster for the next edition of “Hush! Concertos na Praia x Festival do Bem-Estar Desportivo Urbano” is now known, taking place between the 18th and 19th of this month on Hac-Sá beach, Coloane. This Sunday, the 12th, a pre-presentation will take place at Oficinas Navais nº 1, with Lobo and Shing02. There is no shortage of the usual cultural and well-being connection activities Six stages, 40 local bands and singers, two days. These are the numbers for the next edition of “Hush! Concertos na Praia x Festival do Bem-Estar Desportivo Urbano”, scheduled for the 18th and 19th of October on Hac-Sá beach. However, this weekend, namely Sunday, the public in general and music lovers in particular will be able to enjoy a little of what will come later, with the performance of Lobo and the rapper Shing02 at Oficinas Navais nº1. Lobo will present a “DJ set”, showing the sounds he has mixed and created in recent years. A radio broadcaster in the 90s, namely at TDM Rádio Macau and the former Rádio Vilaverde, Lobo founded, in 2000, the independent publisher “4daz-le”, “which remains the only one of its kind to date”, describes the organization of “Hush!”. Also this weekend, but Saturday, the so-called “Festive Prelude” takes place in community neighborhoods, with various community shows, concerts and musical workshops. What promises to be a “marathon” of concerts showcases “the cultural uniqueness of East Asia” on six stages, namely “Hot Wave”, “Music Chill”, “Hush! Kids – Parque Desportivo Infantil”, “Palco Wellfest”, “Jardim Desportivo” and “Desafio Fitness”. Thus, in addition to music, there will be parallel activities such as “SUP Yoga”, the “Music Glow Run”, described as a “musical parade for parents and children”; gastronomy tents and various workshops. The aim of this diversity of offer is to “make the public aware of the uniqueness of the cultural fusion between East and West in Macau and “build the role” of the territory “as an important window for exchange and mutual learning between Chinese and Western civilizations”. Lively sand The main highlight of the festival, however, is the "Hush! Concerts on the Beach", with 40 bands and musicians from Macau taking the stage, in addition to ten international groups, namely SUMMERWARZ, from the interior of China; the Balming Tiger, from South Korea; bassist H.J. Freaks and Muque, a rock group from Japan. Also included is the performance of young ukuleleist Feng E and the female metal band MakeMake, both from Taiwan. Other names that grace the Hac-Sá stage are Concrete/Lotus, Blademark, Roberto Madan, No Rison, WhyOceans, IRIS MONDO, Ying May Supermarket, Cancer Game and Chong River Fusion, among others. Taking into account the celebration of the 20th anniversary of "Hush! Concertos na Praia", the organization decided to invite the organizers of other festivals in Asia, namely the well-known Clockenflap Music & Arts Festival in Hong Kong, the Strawberry Music Festival and the Midi Festival in Mainland China, among others. The idea is to establish “a regional exchange platform and provide presentation contacts for local bands”. On the sports side, the “Urban Sports Wellbeing Festival” brings to Coloane more than 30 professional fitness and yoga instructors from Asia, such as Hong Kong artist and dance instructor Fatboy@ERROR, “Physical: 100 Season 2” champion and South Korean CrossFit “superstar” Amotti, as well as dance trainer Thai, Gun Gun. In total, there will be more than 40 gymnastics and dance classes over two days, designed for beginners or practitioners. The festival organization, which has the support of entities such as the Cultural Institute or the Institute for Municipal Affairs, prepared free bus transport to Coloane, running between Praia de Hac Sá and Iao Hon, Fai Chi Kei, Taipa. The public can also take the free MGM Cotai bus from any port in Macau, with the exception of Qingmao Port, to MGM Cotai Bus Terminal B1, and then use the free event bus service to travel to Hac Sá Beach. The “Hush!” concerts Entrance is free and tickets must be purchased for the “Urban Sports Welfare Festival”.

item.title: NBA | China and Alibaba Cloud sign partnership
item.description: NBA China, the most popular professional sports league on Chinese social media, with 425 million followers, has just signed a partnership with Alibaba Cloud, another Chinese group founded by Jack Ma, to improve the interactivity of basketball fans with the games broadcast, namely the “NBA All-Star”, the NBA playoffs and the finals, using artificial intelligence and the system of cloud computing. The announcement was made by Joe Tsai, co-founder and executive vice president of the Alibaba group and owner of the Brooklyn Nets team, from New York; and by Mark Tatum, deputy commissioner and director of operations at the NBA [National Basketball Association], the main basketball sports league in the USA and one of the most important worldwide. In concrete terms, NBA China “will utilize Alibaba Cloud’s AI and cloud computing services to support a wide range of digital fan engagement initiatives”, having developed “a proprietary AI model for NBA China based on Alibaba’s ‘Qwen’ series of models”. item.title: AMCM | Monthly drop in deposits and loans
item.description: Data from the Macau Monetary and Exchange Authority (AMCM) regarding deposits, loans and money supply reveal that, between July and August, there was a drop in deposits and loans made by residents. Domestic loans granted to the private sector fell by 1.1 percent compared to July, reaching 501.9 billion patacas. In turn, the drop in loans granted abroad was even greater, around 9.1 percent, worth 511.8 billion patacas. Thus, AMCM statistics show that the total volume of loans in banks fell by 5.3 percent between July and August, a drop of 1,013.7 billion patacas. Regarding deposits, the monthly drop was 0.4 percent, amounting to 813.8 billion patacas, while the drop in deposits by non-residents was much greater, in the order of 7.1 percent, amounting to 338.1 billion patacas. AMCM data also shows that “public sector deposits in banking activity grew to 220.9 billion patacas, representing a growth of 5.2 percent”. Thus, in general terms, “total deposits in banking activity registered a decrease of 1.3 percent, reaching 1,372.8 billion patacas”. In monthly terms, monetary circulation grew by 0.3 percent, but current deposits fell by six percent.

item.title: Ana Cristina Alves
item.description: The philosophical questions that will arise throughout this text are based on concrete data, they are not inventions and depend on newspaper reports, but they are certainly not fake news, they just report what has been happening in the second decade of the 21st century in the People's Republic of China. China is the market leader in robotic technology, including humanoid robotics. Robotics malls are growing in Beijing, one with 4 floors, opened on August 7, 2025, another with 6 floors in Shenzhen. In this large shopping mall, there are robots for all tastes and uses in assisting medicine, industry and everyday activities. They can be bionic, with shapes and movements inspired by biology, or humanoid, reaching levels of sophistication like those seen in a chess player named Wukong. We also find them linked to sport, some play boxing, others football, others practice running, there are artists, for example, painters, musicians and dancers, there are medical assistants, masseurs, nursing technicians and laboratory assistants, and/or dedicated to traditional Chinese medicine, there are them committed to daily tasks, making excellent waiters and cooks, who attentively flip pancakes and prepare barbecues, but also counter staff, there are, in addition, humanoid transporters and drones. And if there are good ones, that is, used to help and build, obviously there could be bad ones, to hinder and destroy. But this is a conversation for later. At the World Robotics Conference in August 2025, held in Beijing, a sales balance was carried out for the year 2024 regarding industrial robots, which exceeded 300 thousand units, keeping China in top place in sales of this type of robots for the twelfth consecutive year. In a report made by the President of the Chinese Robotics Institute, Xu Xiaolan (徐晓兰), the country is the largest producer of robotics in the world, with sales of industrial robots having increased from 33,000 in 2015 to 556,000 units in 2024. The production of service robots (domestic services, storage and logistics, commercial services, support for the elderly, the disabled and rehabilitation medical) for more than 10 million units. In statistical terms, and according to data from the International Data Corporation (IDC) for 2024, Chinese manufacturers occupy 84.7% of the global market for commercial service robots. China leads the world robotics market, through its active creative industry, as it had already done in relation, for example, to toys. The country is responsible for around 80% to 90% of toys sold globally, whether old wooden toys, plush toys, inflatable toys, or electronic toys, with Guangdong, Jiangsu and Shandong being the main bases for purchasing toys, with the centers of Fujian, Zhejiang and Shanghai also being strong in this area. Centers that we also find linked to robotics, at least in the case of Shanghai and Shenzhen. Can a relationship be established between toys and robotics in the case of China? Toys are a strong focus of generation Z, short for zoomers, (those from the second half of the 90s until 2010), who fear a bleak future and invest a lot in emotional spending. This generation of the World Wide Web follows the growth of technological devices, being considered digital native. As I believe, the path for the emergence of robots in China was laid out long before Generation Z appeared on the face of the earth. The Chinese have always loved toys, see their love for stuffed animals, lanterns, old wooden toys and, more recently, all types of electronic toys. Now, robots, although they are much more than entertainment, have the appearance of toys, with the added advantage of being able to receive a strong emotional investment, combined with enormous practical utility. These “cans”, made from aluminum, steel and titanium, and plastics, such as polypropylene, ABS and polycarbonate, rubbers and elastomers, in addition to numerous electronic components, such as microprocessors, sensors, motors and wiring, are great companions of humans, faithful friends and obedience only limited to their manufacture. They therefore appear to fulfill several functions and their emergence was only possible due to a close alliance between science and technology, that is, due to the development of technology, which was thematized by great contemporary writers and philosophers in the West, and think of Aldous Huxley (1894-1963) and his futuristic dystopia, entitled Brave New World. 1932), in which a society dominated by genetic engineering is psychologically conditioned, including by drugs (soma), in order to guarantee social well-being and suppress freedom and critical thinking. Consider, also, works such as Oswald Spengler's (1880-1936), Man and Technique from 1931, which explores the relationship between human beings and technology, ultimately leading to self-destruction through the dissolution of Western culture. But if Western culture can feel, to paraphrase Spengler, “nauseated by machines”, there are others like the philosopher Martin Heidegger (1889-1976), who in The Question of Technique (1954) sees technique as the meaning of a new era for human beings. However, to do so it is necessary to know how to question the technique and not just accept it in an instrumental way at the service of anthropological purposes, when humanism for the philosopher of The Letter to Humanism (1946) has disastrous consequences, because it distances the true man from his essence and Being, which is thus hidden and not revealed. None of these paths of Western thought have been followed by the Chinese of our times, strongly committed to the utilitarian use of technology. The instrumentalization of it at the service of humanity, or rather, of China, does not raise existential doubts in them, as is attested by the large robotics shopping malls currently available in Beijing or Shenzhen to a public eager for technological innovations. Chinese robots serve all types of functions; industrial, commercial, scientific, recreational, domestic and emotional assistance. The relative lack of freedom, or the limitation of degrees of freedom (Degrees of Freedom, DOF) also does not seem worrying to them, at least to the point of raising philosophical questions about a dystopian future, viable through the genetic crossing of artificial intelligence with animals, including so-called rational humans. They only seek to improve the degrees of freedom of robots defined as the number of independent movements of their joints and components, carried out in both the rotational and translational directions, these degrees being in the Humanoid Robotic Technology article, published in May 2025, variable according to the technical improvement of each machine: the greatest degree of freedom is presented by the Era-Star 1 Robot. Therefore, do not expect great and unusual innovations regarding the degree of freedom of robots, they will be, until you see, limited and submissive to their creators. From a good creator a positive robot will emerge, from a bad creator, a negative one. A friend with whom I discussed the topic was very surprised by the fact that one of the most populous countries in the world is at the forefront of robotic development, because for him it would be more important to provide employment to a huge population than to seek to replace them in almost all tasks, from scientific to the most routine, such as the transport and delivery of goods. To understand why this total adherence to intelligent machinery, or as intelligent as its limited freedom allows, it is necessary to go back to the history of China. I propose a journey to the times of the emergence and development of the use of gunpowder. The appearance of gunpowder is associated with Alchemy and Taoist masters, who carried out the first scientific experiments in search of the elixir of longevity, already in the Warring States Period (战国 Zhàn Guó, 475-221 BC), being one of the four great inventions of Ancient China (四大发明Sì dà fāmíng). The first type of gunpowder to emerge was black gunpowder (黑火药Hēi huǒyào), the experiments of the alchemists were very well received and encouraged by the dominant power, then the experiments continued during the Eastern Han dynasty (东汉Dōng Hàn, 25-220), with the treatise by Wei Boyang (魏伯阳), entitled Zhouyi Cantongqi, being famous. (《周易参同契》), and translated as The Concordance of the Three, or that of the Jin dynasty (晋代Jìn dài, 266-420) by the great alchemist Ge Hong (葛洪), whose title is Baopuzi, in Portuguese, The Master Who Embraces Simplicity (《抱朴子·仙药篇》), especially its chapter dedicated to the manufacture of the pill of immortality. Perhaps when using combustion methods to create the pill, the alchemists discovered gunpowder by chance by mixing sulfur, saltpeter and charcoal. It is certain that the explosion occurred and the dangerous, flammable and detonating element was discovered, but it is no less certain that the masters did not follow this route, which they considered unproductive for the desired objective. Then only much later during the Song dynasty (宋代Sòng dài， 960-1279) is it known that some artisans established fireworks workshops in Kaifeng to produce rockets and fireworks indispensable for all great moments of celebration in China. The use of gunpowder then followed two very different paths, one pyrotechnic for recreational purposes of the imperial power and associated stately homes, the other for military use. Why is the story of the discovery of gunpowder brought here? Because this could perhaps contain the three dimensions that we can find in the creation and interest in robots in China. Its creation reveals an enormous scientific interest associated: on the one hand, with philosophical practices aimed at developing life to its limits and perhaps even their absence, which would be achieved by immortality; on the other, it expresses an immense recreational desire with deep emotional investment, and, on the other, a practical utility, which puts robotics at the forefront, both in scientific, military and civil terms. The new Chinese philosophy, as the oldest genuinely autochthonous one, appears in close connection with science and techniques with mysterious connections to the world of magic for the Taoist masters of yesterday, who are followed by the great doctors, including those of traditional Chinese medicine, who today find precious laboratory assistants carrying out work of great precision and minimal errors, since robots do not They get tired, they don't even bother, they do what is asked of them without any salary demands. Furthermore, in military terms this arsenal of machinery is an excellent alternative, as it saves lives, as it is complex and autonomous enough to do so. Obviously, of the many ethical issues associated with this exponential development of the new world of robotics and artificial intelligence, one seems essential, above all and, for now, in terms of biotechnical experimentation and related scientific research, which will be discussed below. First the example, taken from the development of dynamic electrodes for brain-computer interface, as is happening at the Shenzhen Institute of Advanced Technology of the Chinese Academy of Sciences. In brain-computer interface systems, electrodes from electronic devices must be connected to the brain to acquire electroencephalographic signals. These electrodes are made of flexible fiber, similar to a worm, with a magnetic sensor incorporated in the head of the “worm”, to be manipulated according to the orientation of external magnetic fields. These flexible fiber electrodes were introduced into the brains of rabbits and also rats, with the aim of subsequently serving human clinical needs, such as intelligent control of prostheses, localization of epileptic lesions and treatment of chronic neurological disorders. From an ethical point of view, the question cannot help but be asked: why are human lives more important than all others on our planet? Human beings remain the kings of creation, even within the scope of philosophies such as the Chinese, whose non-humanist tradition, as referred to in Heidegger's Letter to Humanism, is well known. Are we humans really that valuable? Science must continue its path, which in China will always be followed from a pragmatic and utilitarian perspective for the benefit of the Chinese and the Chinese nation. But don't think that robotics is there just to serve Chinese society without exchanging favors, as we cannot forget the enormous emotional investment that the population that descends from Dragons makes in these new beings, some more bionic than others, who acquire the status of companions and friends and, in this capacity, have all the pampering that was previously due to the humans and animals they chose to cherish. The new Chinese philosophy is utilitarian, practical and has new entities in its world of knowledge, such as humanoids, bionic robots and robotics toys. They are highly esteemed and paving the way for a new era, that of cyborgs or better said, the mixed humanity of tomorrow, which will have the greatest chance of living long and, who knows, immortalizing itself. item.title: Paulo Maia and Carmo
item.description: Zhang Xuan (713-755), the Tang painter, was the author of a painting that today can be admired through a copy attributed to the Song emperor, Huizong (r.1022-63), where beautiful ladies are seen, richly dressed, coiffed and adorned, performing practical tasks of treating fabrics, which one would usually expect to see being carried out by servants of these ladies. In this precious horizontal scroll (ink, color and gold on silk, 37.7 x 466 cm, at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston) where luxury is boasted and which in fact shows the celebration of an annual rite related to the production of silk, which takes place in the Spring, serving as an example for the rest of the Empire, you can see at the end, on the left side, two ladies, one on each side, extending a piece of white silk that a third She is ironing, helped by a young woman. And although one of the ladies bends slightly in her zeal to spread the fabric, nothing seems to be requiring much effort, they all seem to be carrying out a pleasant activity. From that time when a domestic scene that took place among the elite was recreated at court, a painter, perhaps no less erudite, recreated in a modest horizontal scroll (ink and color on silk, 26.1 x 69.2 cm, at the National Palace Museum, in Beijing), an exciting counterpoint to this scene in which two humble ladies are the protagonists. One on each side of the ends of two threads in the painful task of manufacturing a fabric that could be the one that on the other roll the ladies spend time eliminating the wrinkles. The ladies here are not sweet or beautiful like others, but simple country women who depend on physical strength to turn the spinning wheel that allows the family to survive. The sympathy that the painting shows for the poor and virtuous but inglorious lives of these women is notable, which raises perplexity as to who and why it was created. Wang Juzheng, who lived during the Northern Song, was born in Hedong (present-day Yongji, Shanxi) in the reign of Emperor Renzong (1023-63), was the son of a painter and other works attributed to him confirm that this is an exception. However, the appreciation with which it was received can be read in the comment that preclar Zhao Mengfu wrote next to it: «It is a small scroll but the brush work is magnificent, it has a high understanding of life. With its wonderful notes it can well be described as a work worthy of the gods.” And all done with great economy. An older woman will be the grandmother of a boy who plays with a frog stuck on a stick at the beginning of the reel, two old willow trunks and branches, reminding us of the father's absence, a not-so-young woman sitting on a wooden bench moves the spinning wheel and, as soon as you see it, she has a baby on her chest, in front of her the family's small dog plays. In the hands of the tired old woman, two threads carry tremendous weight.

item.title: Today Macau
item.description: The Secretary for Social Affairs and Culture, O Lam, defended the continuation, by the General Association of Overseas Chinese of Macau, of the work to promote the territory, at a time when the entity celebrated, on Wednesday, 57 years of existence. According to a statement, O Lam said, in a speech, that the association should promote the specific advantages of Macau as a Sino-Lusophone platform in addition to assuming the bridge between China, Portugal and Portuguese-speaking countries, as well as Spanish-speaking countries. Lam also hopes that the association will continue to support local and Mainland Chinese companies in accessing international markets, in addition to supporting the import of certain international projects to China. This is so that Macau can explore the “circle of friends” and partners at an international level, supporting the country’s development in opening up to the outside world.

First the example, taken from the development of dynamic electrodes for brain-computer interface, as is happening at the Shenzhen Institute of Advanced Technology of the Chinese Academy of Sciences. In brain-computer interface systems, electrodes from electronic devices must be connected to the brain to acquire electroencephalographic signals. These electrodes are made of flexible fiber, similar to a worm, with a magnetic sensor incorporated in the head of the “worm”, to be manipulated according to the orientation of external magnetic fields. These flexible fiber electrodes were introduced into the brains of rabbits and also rats, with the aim of subsequently serving human clinical needs, such as intelligent control of prostheses, localization of epileptic lesions and treatment of chronic neurological disorders. From an ethical point of view, the question cannot help but be asked: why are human lives more important than all others on our planet? Human beings remain the kings of creation, even within the scope of philosophies such as the Chinese, whose non-humanist tradition, as referred to in Heidegger's Letter to Humanism, is well known. Are we humans really that valuable? Science must continue its path, which in China will always be followed from a pragmatic and utilitarian perspective for the benefit of the Chinese and the Chinese nation. But don't think that robotics is there just to serve Chinese society without exchanging favors, as we cannot forget the enormous emotional investment that the population that descends from Dragons makes in these new beings, some more bionic than others, who acquire the status of companions and friends and, in this capacity, have all the pampering that was previously due to the humans and animals they chose to cherish. The new Chinese philosophy is utilitarian, practical and has new entities in its world of knowledge, such as humanoids, bionic robots and robotics toys. They are highly esteemed and paving the way for a new era, that of cyborgs or better said, the mixed humanity of tomorrow, which will have the greatest chance of living long and, who knows, immortalizing itself.
